node.text: The fast-spreading #deltavariant is raising fresh health concerns even in places where Covid vaccination rates are high. Senior pharmaceuticals analyst Sam Fazeli is here to tell you what you need to know.

node.title: Your Biggest Delta Variant Questions Answered

node.text:
"Donald Trump upended the American presidency after stepping away from the company that made him rich and famous. Four years later, returning to his empire after losing the White House, what he finds may upend him," write Sophie Alexander and Max Abelson.

"Three quarters of Trump's net worth is tied up in urban real estate. And urban real estate has been hammered by Covid-19," Tim O'Brien tells @quicktake's Tim Stenovec.

The former president's net worth is down to $2.3 billion from $3 billion in 2016. The pandemic he promised would disappear is walloping his company, and the riot that got him impeached for a second time is wounding his brand.

Check out "Trump’s Ailing Empire" on bloomberg.com/graphics to see just how deep in peril he really is.

node.text:
👻 Snap Inc. is rolling out a new tool for its Snapchat app to feature popular videos, called Spotlight, and said it will pay out $1 million a day to creators of the top-performing posts. How good of a deal is that?

🤳🏻 "The more remarkable thing about Snap is that it wasn't offering these sort of incentives to people to create good content previously."

Alex Webb joined @quicktake's Tim Steno to explain why Snap decided to compensate viral creators.

#snapchat #influencer #app #creators #snap

node.title: Snapchat to Pay $1 Million a Day to Creators

node.text:
It’s been 20 months since a pair of fatal crashes forced regulators around the globe to ground the once top-selling jet. The FAA finally approved the Max to resume commercial flights today, which will allow Boeing to make money off the roughly 450 Max jets it has built but not yet delivered.

After the longest grounding of an aircraft in modern U.S. history, it’s reasonable to ask whether the plane is safe. Bloomberg Opinion columnists Chris Bryant and Brooke Sutherland teamed up to discuss the future of the Max, and whether or not they'd be willing to board one.

#Boeing #Boeing737 #737max #airplane #aircraft #airline #southwest #americanair #flight #pandemic #livestream #video #igtv #travel

node.title: Boeing’s 737 Max Is Back. Are You Willing to Board?

node.text:
Frank Barry didn’t ask a soul about Donald Trump or Joe Biden on his @looking4lincoln trip. For the two months he spent crossing the country along the Lincoln Highway by Winnebago, talking with Americans and hoping to reach San Francisco by Election Day, he never brought up the campaign. Sometimes he knew how people felt — occasionally they would say, though usually not. But it didn’t matter. He wasn’t running a focus group. He was trying to catch glimpses of a more enduring spirit, the kind that has transcended parties and generations, the kind that lives, as Lincoln said, in the better angels of our nature. And maybe those glimpses could help us see more of ourselves in each other, and in the land we share.

#lincolnhighway #travel #rv #roadtrip #winnebago #highway #ontheroad #interview #video

node.title: The End of the Lincoln Highway

node.text:
“It was really impossible not to feel the immediacy, the urgency of climate change on this leg of the trip.”

Frank Barry stops in #Iowa and #Colorado, continuing his journey across the U.S. along the Lincoln Highway.

Video by @quicktake, footage by @looking4lincoln.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on July 31, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Isittime to stop obsessively counting every Covid case? BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
The impulse to count every case has become debilitating. It’s time to focus on a more informative set of data, writes Rachel Rosenthal.

Singapore’s data obsession has been one of its virtues throughout the pandemic. It’s easy to parse and you can almost set your clock to the government’s WhatsApp updates detailing the number of locally transmitted cases and imported ones.

But now there's an argument for focusing on the figures that really matter: vaccination rates, serious cases and deaths. 

If Singapore wants to go back to trying to live with the virus, it must interpret the data in ways that will make its people feel safe, not fearful.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on July 31, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Bad news: Pretty much every delicious thingis getting pricier Price increase Fewer Promotions Sports Drinks Trading Up Tea and coffee Fizzy drinks Milk Hot cereals Bread Water Beer Salty snacks Cookies -5 10 15 20% Source:IRI Consumer Ûackged Goods Demand BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
So it looks like we'll be paying for inflation then, with more expensive bread, beer and snacks. 😭

Consistent but modest inflation gets shoppers used to price rises. For grocers, when food prices are accelerating, they have to sell fewer cans of beans or loaves of bread to reach the same value of sales. So long as they keep volumes stable, sales automatically rise.

The problem is, the cost increases, not to mention rising labor expenses amid worker shortages on both sides of the Atlantic, are neither gradual nor consistent right now, writes @andrea_felsted.

Tap the link in our bio to read more.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on July 31, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, outdoors and text that says 'The pandemic has made going on vacation the opposite of relaxing BloombergOpinion Bloomber'.

node.text:
In 2010, Dutch researchers discovered that most people who go on holiday trips are no happier when they return.

Some of that has to do with working extra hard before the break in order to be able to take it, then extra hard afterward to catch up, and worrying in between about what’s happening in your inbox. But it also has to do with planning the trip, and fretting about things going wrong. Then Covid-19 came along and made everything so much worse.

Andreas Kluth speaks from experience. Just trying to figure out where he could go on holiday was hard enough: "At some point, every European country seemed to be doing its own thing, some keeping people out, others requiring quarantine exactly as long as the average vacation, and others yet welcoming everybody with proof of vaccination, negative tests or past infection. As to more exotic destinations, from non-EU Britain to the Americas and beyond, we stopped googling when we couldn’t even agree how to keep track of the various regulations and updates."

Tap the link in our bio to read more.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on July 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Flu season used to be no big deal. After Covid, that just looks silly. Flu vaccine rates in England and U.S. England U.S. Ages 65 and older Health care workers Ages 10 Ages 6 months to under 65 (at risk) Pregnant people Ages Ages 6 months to4 Ages 65 and older Ages Ages 13 17 Ages 50 64 Ages 25 I 50 Source:U.K.'sPublicHealth 75% BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
🌡️What happens when you layer flu on top of Covid-19?

"We don’t really know, since last winter saw an incredibly mild flu season, mostly due to measures such as lockdowns, social distancing and masking. Infections rates for flu were two-thirds lower than during the 2011-2012 season, which had record low rates," writes Therese Raphael.

We can’t count on a repeat. The low prevalence of flu last year makes it harder to predict which strains to include in this winter’s vaccine. We could get lucky again, or things could get worse: Lowered levels of natural immunity after a few low-flu seasons could make it easier for new variants to take hold.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how we should prepare.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on July 30, 2021. May be an image of 7 people and text that says '69% of China's athletes at the Tokyo Olympics are women CHINA 15 JA BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
🏀In China’s sports world, there are big balls and there are small balls. During the Olympic season, fans and government officials pay particular attention to the country’s performance in what are known as the “three big balls”: basketball, soccer and volleyball. They’re perceived as high-prestige events in which an emerging superpower should be competitive.

⚽️This year, China’s women qualified in all three sports. And for the first time in 37 years, the men’s teams didn’t advance in any. In total, 298 of the 431 Chinese athletes at #tokyo2020 are women.

🏐How come there's such a difference? The Communist Party under Xi Jinping has often fretted about the alleged feminization of adolescent males and — at a very high level — demanded more gym classes to rectify the problem. Meanwhile, the government has been cracking down on women’s-rights activists online.

🇨🇳The success of China’s Olympic women comes as a sort of patriotic rebuke to those policies, writes Adam Minter. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

#china #basketball #women #tokyo2020

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on July 29, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, fire, outdoors and text that says 'us or does this feel like the apocalypse? BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
🔥 A global pandemic, disastrous floods, huge wildfires and the near-breakdown of political order in many nations. Poor humanity just can’t catch a break these days.

Is it coincidence that these unfortunate events have all happened at the same time? Niall Ferguson says not: "We can see that there are connections between these disasters — and that they are in fact parts of interlocking trends"

Our current population of 7.9 billion humans is currently threatening to destabilize the planet. As if to curb our numbers, our technological advances and demographic expansion have created ideal conditions for significant, life-shortening disasters.

This is not to say that we cannot overcome these problems. In fact, history suggests we can. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on July 29, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Disney should know better than to battle Scarlett Johansson Source: Marvel Studios BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
🎬 "Black Widow” star Scarlett Johansson is reminding Hollywood that at least one group still favors the box office: the actors who were promised a big pay day from it. Mess with that and you just might hear from their lawyers.

"For companies like Disney, it’s the overlooked cost of going all in on streaming, where tangled rights deals and prickly contracts are making for a messy transition," writes Tara Lachapelle.

“Scarlett Johansson Sues Disney” is quite the eye-catching headline. A brand known for expertly averting scandal is on bad terms with the current star of its biggest film franchise — a development almost more enticing than the superhero plot itself.

Disney+'s decision to send "Black Widow" to streaming may have shortchanged Johansson by some $50 million.

Will she get her payday? Tap the link in our bio to read more.

#blackwidow #disney #lawsuit #scarlettjohansson

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on July 29, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Americans slept more during the pandemic, but was Change in minutes per day from 2019 to 2020 Watching television Sleeping 18.6 Lawn and garden care 10.2 4.2 Telephone calls, mail and e-mail 4.2 Housework 4.2 Parttgn sports, exercise and recreation 3.0 Food preparation and cleanup Caring for and helping household members 2.4 1.2 Eating and drinking Caring for and helping nonhousehold members 0.6 0.6 Bureau Labor Statistics American Time Use Survey BloombergOpinion Bloomberg'.

node.text:
😴 2020 was a pretty bad year for everyone, right? But hey, at least we seem to have gotten more sleep!

Sleeping time went up 1.9% from 2019 to 2020, and 3.2% from 2003 to 2019. The rise over the past two decades is pretty evenly distributed by age, with every group under 65 getting more sleep in 2019 than 2003, which is pretty good.

But Justin Fox says there's a catch: "Not all the available evidence points in the same encouraging direction...One thing that can be said with some confidence is that we are getting less sleep than in the age before the electric light."

In 1942, when home televisions were rare and many rural areas still didn’t have electricity, average hours slept was about an hour longer than in recent polls. What's more, while some Americans are able to get a better night's sleep, an increasing number of workers are likely to be a short sleeper. That is to say, we're entering an era of sleep inequality. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

#sleep #tv #atus #survey #sleeping #statistics

node.text: The fast-spreading #deltavariant is raising fresh health concerns even in places where Covid vaccination rates are high. Senior pharmaceuticals analyst Sam Fazeli is here to tell you what you need to know.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on July 28, 2021. May be an image of 3 people, people standing, suit and text that says 'Why Republicans should give Joe Biden his infrastructure deal BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
If Republicans support the president now on infrastructure, they can watch Democrats fight among themselves later, writes Matthew Yglesias. 

Negotiators from the two parties have an agreement on a bipartisan infrastructure framework, or BIF. What they don’t yet have are the 10 Republican votes it would take to overcome a Senate filibuster. 

If Republicans are smart, however, they’ll sign on the dotted line even though it means letting Biden take a victory lap — not just on the infrastructure bill but also on his unrealistic-sounding promise to unify the country.

If they kill the BIF, Republicans will prove the progressive skeptics right and be trying the patience of even moderate Democrats, making more progressive policy more likely.

Click the link in our bio to read the full column.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on July 28, 2021. May be an image of ‎2 people, child, people standing and ‎text that says '‎Will we ever be able to travel with young kids? A ایر BloombergOpinion‎'‎‎.

node.text:
Countries around the world are attempting to reopen their borders. But officials haven't even considered the most basic question: What to do about kids?

Covid vaccines aren't available for young children yet, but most governments impose strict guidelines for unvaccinated individuals on this group, which comprises about a fifth of the global population. "The burden is borne by the entire family," writes Anjani Trivedi.

Some nations have done better than others, but the rules are inconsistent. 🇺🇸 In the U.S., children are treated as unvaccinated. 🇦🇺 In Australia, children under 4 are exempt from testing and those younger than 11 aren’t required to wear masks on planes. 🇫🇷 In France, measures applicable to vaccinated adults apply to minors accompanying them.

"If countries are now brave enough to host massive sporting events and arts festivals, surely there are ways to ensure parents and children can cross borders safely to reunite and to relieve brimming social anxiety," says Trivedi.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about when we'll be able to travel with young kids.

May be an image of text that says 'Everyoneissplashing splashing out Louis Vuitton handbags Louis Vuitton fashion and leather goods organic sales 150% 100 50 Q1 Q1 2009 2010 Q1 2011 Q1 2012 Q1 Q1 Q1 Q1 2013 2014 2015 2016 loomberg Intelligence Q1 2017 -50 Q1 Q1 Q1 Q1 2018 2019 2020 2021 BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
👜Louis Vuitton sales rose by 122% in the second quarter, compared with the year earlier. And it's not just LVMH who's seen demand soar: Waiting lists for brightly colored Rolex watches are long. Gucci sandals and Prada bucket hats are among this season’s most wanted items. Burberry and Richemont have seen sales soar past 2019 levels.

Wherever you look, shoppers can’t seem to get enough luxury fashion goods.

But @andrea_felsted says these heady times might not last forever: "Many purchases of high-end goods over the last year were fueled by shoppers having little else to spend on. As economies continue to open up, there will be more competition from the hospitality sectors."

Tap the link in our bio to read more.
